item.title: Ticket #5070 (Unauthorized administrator registration) created
item.dc:creator: Emu
item.description:
Hello.

About a month I found in my registered users one that have admin rights. Then I removed his rights and schedule investigation of problem to "tomorrow". Today I found another co-administrator in my user list. I tried to investigate the problem, but I couldn't find the way to reproduce issue. Access log was not enough.

My blog is currently 2.2.3 version of WordPress.

I can post access log records for that user if it can help.

I think that is very dangerous, so I'll put "highest omg bbq" priority.

Regards, Emu

P.S. The problem can be in some of my installed plugins, so I'll continue investigating. P.P.S. Sorry for my bad english. I hope you understand me.

item.title: Ticket #5069 (Theme Name not guaranteed unique, collision handling missing) created
item.dc:creator: andy
item.description:
In working on adding a newer version of a theme to an installation, it was noted that some functions rely on the theme name being unique. For instance, the wrong stylesheet path would be returned. The "Theme Name" in style.css should not be relied upon for uniqueness; only the directory can be counted upon because the filesystem prevents collisions.

Proposed: refactor theme system to use dirname exclusively for referencing the active theme/stylesheet.

item.title: Ticket #5066 (Anonymize update checking) updated
item.dc:creator: johnbillion
item.description:
Actually scrap that last comment.

A good move would be to delay 2.3 by a day or two in order to prepare a bullet-proof press release explaining in detail what the update notification system is, how it works, and what information will be sent by it (for both the core updates and plugin updates). The aim of it being to reassure people that this is a good thing™. Because it is.

item.title: Ticket #5066 (Anonymize update checking) updated
item.dc:creator: johnbillion
item.description:
I know it's stupidly close to the line, but I think it would be a good move to delay 2.3 and get this into 2.3. Putting it in 2.4 or even 2.3.1 will be too late for the tinfoil hat brigade.

Note that I couldn't give a shit. I'm thinking of the PR here.

item.title: Ticket #5063 (Potential type mismatch in post cron hooks) updated
item.dc:creator: Otto42
item.description:
The specific-ness of the args requirement can indeed be somewhat annoying at times.

Suggest making a function that will allow somebody to clear a hook without knowing the args at all. Given only the hook name, remove all scheduled references to it, period. It would help with cleanup functions, such as those when deactivating a plugin.

item.title: Ticket #5062 (Adding Tags to Pages) updated
item.dc:creator: zamoose
item.description:
Categorization and metadata are two different things. I view tags as the latter, and thus I definitely see utility in allowing for tagging of pages.

+1 from me.

item.title: Ticket #4833 (browse_happy() isn't used anywhere, remove it) updated
item.dc:creator: f00f
item.description: The wide-spread browse-happy plugin (TM). Honestly, I was also talking about all the other functions that are not referenced. And it is just good practice to not simply delete a function from one version to another.

item.title: Ticket #4994 (Default Timezone settings) updated
item.dc:creator: darkdragon
item.description:
How the default works is that you set it first and then you change it whenever you need to. The DateTime classes allow you to create timezones on the fly, so it wouldn't be an issue if PHP4 compatibility wasn't required. However, you can still change it when you get passed the point where the option file is included and have access to that API.

It should probably be a function, in that case.

item.title: Ticket #5057 (cannot remove all categories from a post) updated
item.dc:creator: JeremyVisser
item.description: It is on purpose. When WP 2.1 was in development, when saving a post that didn't have any categories selected, WP would automatically select the default category.

item.title: Ticket #5027 (Give showinabox.tv a branch for development) updated
item.dc:creator: JeremyVisser
item.description: Also, if it's non-trivial (i.e. requires core hacking), there is nothing more you would gain from being hosted in Automattic's repo, than just svn merge'ing from WordPress in your own. It would work exactly the same.

Highly agree with Viper: Pages aren't posts. Pages are categorised/given context by their hierarchy within the page tree, not by categories or tags.

I say wontfix.

I say include it. Those that don't want HTML in their titles can simply not use any.

item.title: Ticket #4170 (author pages do an uncached user_nicename lookup) updated
item.dc:creator: f00f
item.description: Looks ok. I agree with rob1n that the function name should be changed. Furthermore IMHO the cache name should also reflect that user ids are cached, not nicenames. I'd call it user_id_by_nicename or sth. like that.

item.title: Ticket #4287 (Links widget has duplicate ID issue) updated
item.dc:creator: docwhat
item.description:
The impact of this bug is rather serious. I don't know why it keeps getting bumped even though there is a simple one line fix for it. It may not be the *best* fix, but it is a fix and it'll work reliably.

Without it CSS and JavaScript cannot do the right thing with respect to the link widget and the (X)HTML is not valid. This is a huge problem for themes like Sandbox, where you need the markup to be valid to get the CSS to work.

Ciao!

item.title: Ticket #5065 (Unify User-Agent strings) created
item.dc:creator: docwhat
item.description:
In WordPress 2.3, there are either 10 or 11 places where User-Agent strings are created.

I would like to suggest adding a function, wp_user_agent() which would generate the base User-Agent including things like PHP version and bloginfo('url'). It could optionally take an array (in hash form) to append extra values, like Akismet version, etc.

Example Usage: 

$http_response .= "User-Agent: ".wp_user_agent(Array('Akismet' => '2.0'));

This would prevent repetition of code and allow for admins or plugin developers to add or remove information they are not comfortable sending out.

Ciao!

item.title: Ticket #5063 (Potential type mismatch in post cron hooks) created
item.dc:creator: tellyworth
item.description:
The wp cron functions are very picky about argument types. For example, if I do this: 

$post_id = '123';
wp_schedule_single_event($time, 'foo', array($post_id));
wp_clear_scheduled_hook('foo', (int)$post_id);

..the hook won't get cleared as expected, because the type of the post_id argument doesn't match (string vs int) even though its value is the same. That's an easy mistake to make: in wp-includes/post.php, post ID's are passed around that are variously strings or ints at different places in the code. I'm not aware of any code that currently breaks, but it's a bug waiting to happen.

To add to the confusion, Wordpress and Wordpress-mu store cron hooks with different post ID types: Wordpress uses a string, Wordpress-mu uses an int.

I'm not sure what the solution is, but it's probably worth noting somewhere.

item.title: Ticket #5062 (Adding Tags to Pages) created
item.dc:creator: thee17
item.description:
On Line 152 of page wp-admin/edit-page-form.php if you add 

<fieldset id="tagdiv">
	<legend><?php _e('Tags (separate multiple tags with commas: cats, pet food, dogs)'); ?></legend>
	<div><input type="text" name="tags_input" class="tags-input" id="tags-input" size="30" tabindex="3" value="<?php echo get_tags_to_edit( $post_ID ); ?>" /></div>
</fieldset>

Then you can add tagging to pages, as this problem was discribed on the wp-testers mailing list on Sept 23rd

item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: Not an purpose. Definitely a bug.

item.title: Ticket #5057 (cannot remove all categories from a post) created
item.dc:creator: Denis-de-Bernardy
item.description:
When a post has any number of categories, you cannot deselect them all. If you do so, WP ignores the category update altogether and sticks with the old set of categories.

This might arguably be on purpose, but if so it's a bit odd in that in the last version of WP a post could have no categories.

item.dc:creator: Denis-de-Bernardy
item.description:

It might just be my own site that had corrupt data, but it's still worth doing a quick check imho.

item.title: Ticket #5054 (Extend search with simple keyword to negate) created
item.dc:creator: snakefoot
item.description:
Would be nice if the default search in Wordpress could perform recognition of negated search (Exclude pages that contains term):

-term

But if quotes are used then it should not be recognised as a negation:

"-term"

item.title: Ticket #5034 (Impossible to have duplicate category slugs with different parents) updated
item.dc:creator: snakefoot
item.description: Should I create a new ticket for 2.4 so this one can get closed ?

item.title: Ticket #4803 (WordPress should be inserting its generator tag via the wp_head hook) updated
item.dc:creator: JeremyVisser
item.description: Unless Automattic creates a spider and crawls the entire World Wide Web looking for generator tags, I don't think it's actually possible to generate stats based on that tag.

item.title: Ticket #5053 (phpDoc for Plugin.php function _wp_filter_build_unique_id) created
item.dc:creator: darkdragon
item.description:
The attached file adds phpDoc documentation to the _wp_filter_build_unique_id() function in wp-includes/plugin.php file.

It doesn't seem right to have all of the rest of the functions documented and have one at the bottom without. Just not beautiful, and beauty is awesome.

item.title: Ticket #4742 (phpdoc for taxonomy API) updated
item.dc:creator: darkdragon
item.description:
Added a patch that almost completely covers the parameters and return values. Missing mostly cache functions.

This patch still doesn't completely cover the short and long descriptions for most of the functions. If anyone wants to help out with that, be my guess. I figure that at least the parameters and return types might be useful at this point of time.

item.title: taxonomy.6159.phpdoc.patch attached to Ticket #4742
item.dc:creator: darkdragon
item.description: More phpDoc for revision 6159, still incomplete.

item.title: Ticket #5051 (Pages' names containing & don't get escaped) closed
item.dc:creator: Viper007Bond
item.description:
worksforme:

Unable to reproduce using the default theme.

item.title: Ticket #5052 (wp_list_bookmarks() generates the same ID for each link category) created
item.dc:creator: znuff
item.description:
Using wp_list_bookmarks() generates the same id="links" for all link categories one person could have.

According to the HTML specs, id should be unique. Thus every theme that uses wp_get_bookmarks() will fail validation.

item.title: Ticket #5048 (Update jQuery form plugin) updated
item.dc:creator: filosofo
item.description:
Replying to Viper007Bond:

No, it's waiting for 2.4. There were some compatibility issues to be dealt with if I remember correctly. Look around -- there's a few tickets on it already.

I think you're thinking of the interface jQuery plugin, not the form plugin. Unlike interface, form is not currently being used in trunk WP, so there could not be any compatibility problems.

item.title: Ticket #5051 (Pages' names containing & don't get escaped) created
item.dc:creator: znuff
item.description: If you create a page with the title containing a &, like q&a, the & sign won't be escaped in the generated html code (&) in the $page_title variable, thus failing html validation.

item.title: Ticket #5048 (Update jQuery form plugin) updated
item.dc:creator: Viper007Bond
item.description:
Keywords changed

Speaking of which, could we please, please include the newest version of the jQuery form plugin, which I've attached, in 2.3?

No, it's waiting for 2.4. There were some compatibility issues to be dealt with if I remember correctly. Look around -- there's a few tickets on it already.

item.title: Ticket #5049 (IE, Write Post, pressing Tab from Title skips over Post to Tags) closed
item.dc:creator: Viper007Bond
item.description:
worksforme:

Works fine for me using FF 2.0.0.7. 

<input type="text" name="post_title" size="30" tabindex="1" value="" id="title" />

<textarea class='mceEditor' rows='25' cols='40' name='content' tabindex='2' id='content'></textarea>

Note the tabindex'es.
